result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (3rd) and Operating w/ PAC (3rd). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (3rd) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (3rd) was dismissed by the court.

  • Dakota Alden Marx was found guilty of OWI (3rd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Dakota Alden Marx was found guilty of Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
--Revocation of drivers license for 30 months

--6 demerit points assessed
--Ignition Interlock Device required on any vehicle driven by the Defendant for a 30 month period

--AODA assessment and follow through with recommended treatment

--Victim impact panel attendance

In Case #22CF56-Count #1 the Court sentences Mr. Marx to serve 6 months in Jail with Huber consecutive to any other sentence in being.  The Court STAYS the sentence, and places Defendant on Probation for two years. As to all three jail terms the Court does not allow the use of electronic monitoring, and the Court does not allow the transfer of service of the jail term to another county.
Consecutive to: any other sentence in being

miscConds.notes: --as to Case #22CF56-Count #1 only: to pay a fine of $ 1800 + costs, along with $61.13 in blood testing fees incurred by the Jefferson Police Department

--to maintain absolute sobriety:  no possession or consumption of alcohol, no possession or consumption of controlled substances without a valid prescription 

--to take all prescriptions as prescribed

--no presence in bars, taverns or liquor stores

--no operation of a motor vehicle without a valid Driver's License and Agent Approval

--to comply with all conditions of Jefferson County Alcohol Treatment Court

--to undergo any assessment, treatment or counseling as required by the Agent

timeConds.notes:
--As to Case #22CF56-Count #1 only: To serve 45 days conditional jail, to be served as follows 15 days in the Jefferson County Jail, with work release privileges; to commence forthwith followed immediately by 30 days on Scram Cam (as approved by the Memorandum of Understanding signed by the Jefferson County Sheriff). "Good time" credit to be applied to both components of order. Release shall be allowed for AA and/or NA meetings.  The Court allows one 24 hour furlough for a religious or nationally recognized holiday. This 24 hour period will not count as time spent serving the sentence, and instead the period of conditional jail will end 24 hours later than it otherwise would have. The requirements of such a furlough period are as set forth on the Criminal Case Settlement form. 

--to comply with DNA sample

--an additional 200 days conditional jail time is imposed and stayed.  This additional conditional jail time can be used at the discretion of the Treatment Court Judge and his/her designee for sanctions.  If the Defendant completes Treatment Court, any remaining conditional jail time will be permanently stayed. However if the Defendant is removed from Treatment Court then this conditional jail term shall be served

records.addlTxt: w/ elements and ccs
Huber

[MK] cases #21CM217, #21CF334, #21CT427, #22CF56 called at 2:44pm.  
Defendant Dakota A Marx in court, in custody, with Attorney Amber Rumpf.  ADA Jeffrey Shock in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
Maximum penalties recited; Constitutional rights reviewed; pleas of " Guilty  " are entered on Case #21CF334-Count #1, and on Case #22CF56-Counts #1 and #8; factual basis stipulated; the Court accepts the pleas, finds Defendant guilty, and orders Judgments of Conviction entered.

On Motion of the State, the Court reads-in and dismisses the remaining counts in cases #21CF334 and #22CF56, and Case #21CT427 and Case #21CM217.

In Case #22CF56-Count #1 the Court sentences Mr. Marx to serve 6 months in Jail with Huber consecutive to any other sentence in being.  
in Case #22CF56-Count #8 the Court sentences Mr. Marx to serve 30 days in Jail with Huber consecutive to Count #1.  
In Case #21CF334-Count #1 the Court sentences Mr. Marx to serve 5 months in Jail with Huber privileges consecutive to Case #22CF56 and any other sentence in being .
As to all three jail terms the Court does not allow the use of electronic monitoring, and the Court does not allow the transfer of service of the jail term to another county.  

The Court STAYS the sentence, and places Defendant on Probation for two years , with conditions:
 --As to Case #22CF56-Count #1 only: To serve 45 days conditional jail, to be served as follows 15 days in the Jefferson County Jail, with work release privileges; to commence forthwith followed immediately by 30 days on Scram Cam (as approved by the Memorandum of Understanding signed by the Jefferson County Sheriff). "Good time" credit to be applied to both components of order. Release shall be allowed for AA and/or NA meetings.  The Court allows one 24 hour furlough for a religious or nationally recognized holiday. This 24 hour period will not count as time spent serving the sentence, and instead the period of conditional jail will end 24 hours later than it otherwise would have. The requirements of such a furlough period are as set forth on the Criminal Case Settlement form. 
--an additional 200 days conditional jail time is imposed and stayed.  This additional conditional jail time can be used at the discretion of the Treatment Court Judge and his/her designee for sanctions.  If the Defendant completes Treatment Court, any remaining conditional jail time will be permanently stayed. However if the Defendant is removed from Treatment Court then this conditional jail term shall be served
--to comply with all conditions of Jefferson County Alcohol Treatment Court
--to maintain absolute sobriety:  no possession or consumption of alcohol, no possession or consumption of controlled substances without a valid prescription 
--to take all prescriptions as prescribed
--no presence in bars, taverns or liquor stores
--no operation of a motor vehicle without a valid Driver's License and Agent Approval
--to undergo any assessment, treatment or counseling as required by the Agent
--to comply with DNA sample pro
--as to Case #22CF56-Count #1 only: to pay a fine of $ 1800 + costs, along with $61.13 in blood testing fees incurred by the Jefferson Police Department
--as to Case #22CF56-Count #8 and Case #21CF334-Count #1: to pay statutory costs and DNA surcharges 

In Case #22CF56-Count #1 the Court orders outright: 
--Revocation of drivers license for 30 months
--AODA assessment and follow through with recommended treatment
--Victim impact panel attendance
--Ignition Interlock Device required on any vehicle driven by the Defendant for a 30 month period  
--6 demerit points assessed

The Judgment of Conviction to indicate: "ALCOHOL TREATMENT COURT PARTICIPANT" 
Attorney Rumpf requests that the posted $500 Cash Bond be returned to the Bond Surety who is the Defendant's father, and he is present in court. 
The Court indicates that, if it is able to do so, the Court is ordering that the $500 posted cash bail funds are to be returned to the Bond Surety.  
recess 3:10pm

Status conference on September 8, 2022 at 01:30 pm.

[MK] cases #21CM217, #21CF334, #21CT427, #22CF56 called at 10:06am 
Defendant Dakota A. Marx  in court, in custody, with Attorney Amber Rumpf. ADA Brookellen Teuber appears for the State of Wisconsin.
In Case #22CF56 Prelim-Waiver and Arraignment are held:  
--Mr. Marx waives his right to Preliminary Hearing; the Court accepts this waiver and binds him over for Trial.
--service of Information admitted, reading waived; the charges and maximum penalties are recited
--pleas of "not guilty" are entered
--in response to the Court's inquiry, both counsel indicate they are not requesting speedy trial.
recess 10:11am

NEXT:   (1) Pretrial Conference on August 17th at 9:00am    (2) Status Conference on September 8th at 1:30pm
Preliminary hearing on August 15, 2022 at 10:00 am.

--no acts or threats of violence towards any person
--to maintain absolute sobriety:  no possession or consumption of alcohol; no possession or consumption of controlled substances without a valid prescription;  to take prescription medications only as prescribed
--no possession of any dangerous weapons
--not to discuss the case with his mother outside of the presence of counsel
--no operation of a motor vehicle without valid drivers license 
--Defendant is to report to the Jefferson County Sheriff's Office for booking (fingerprints and photographs)
--The Defendant is to report and comply with SCRAM alcohol monitoring program as administered by Wisconsin Community Services.  The Court orders the defendant to SCRAM monitoring through WCS, with the consideration of Remote Breath as an alternative only when WCS verifies that a defendant's work environment or health condition prohibits the SCRAM bracelet.
The Defendant is to comply with all SCRAM Program conditions of participation including payment of program costs and fees.  The Defendant is to report for SCRAM installation in Room 230 of the Jefferson County Courthouse on 3/7/22 at 1:00 pm.  **If in custody, release on SCRAM only.**

[ma] Cases 21CM217, 21CF334, 21CT427,22CF56 called at 1:15 PM 
Defendant Dakota A Marx appears via videoconferencing from the Jefferson County Jail, in custody, along with Public Defender Amber Rumpf.  Public Service Special Prosecutor Melanie Flint appears for the State of Wisconsin. 

The Court finds that the video-connection is sight and sound sufficient. 

The Court reviews the court records. 

Atty Rumpf gives explanation for Mr. Marx's non appearance. 

Bond Arguments given by Counsel 

The Court does not forfeit any of the bonds, instead modifies.

As to Case 21CM217: The Court requires a $200 cash bond, with same conditions.
As to Case 21CF334:The Court requires a $200 cash bond, with same conditions.
As to Case 21CT427:The Court requires a $200 cash bond, with same conditions.
As to Case 22CF56: The Court requires a $700 cash bond, with same conditions. 

The Court schedules preliminary hearing within time limits at the request of Atty Rumpf
recess 1:26  pm.

Defendant Dakota A Marx does not appear. Attorney Amber Rumpf appears. ADA Jeffrey Shock appears for the State of Wisconsin.
Case #22CF56 is scheduled for Preliminary Hearing today and the State's officer-witness is present.  
Attorney Rumpf reports that she got a message from Mr. Marx this morning, indicating that he is at home with his daughter who is ill, and that Mr. Marx indicates to have a Covid test later today and he will provide documentation of this.
The Court issues Warrants-Body Only, returnable to any Jefferson County magistrate, indicating that the Court will revisit the warrants-status if verification-documentation is received.
Attorney Rumpf indicates that Mr. Marx's current address is:  400 Jackson Street, Fort Atkinson WI  53538
.recess 8:37am
